title: Diabetic Ketoacidosis in Newly Diagnosed Type 1 DM
chief_complaint: Vomiting, abdominal pain, and rapid breathing for 2 days
presentation: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the ER with vomiting, diffuse abdominal pain, rapid deep breathing, and drowsiness for 2 days. He has had polyuria, polydipsia, and 6 kg weight loss over the past month. His parents thought it was a stomach infection. He has a fruity odor on his breath.
history: Polyuria and polydipsia for 1 month. Weight loss 6 kg. Increased appetite initially, then anorexia for 1 week. Vomiting for 2 days (bilious). Diffuse abdominal pain (may mimic acute abdomen). Rapid deep breathing (Kussmaul). Progressively drowsy. Fruity breath odor. No prior DM diagnosis. No family history of T1DM. No recent illness or steroid use.
physical_exam: Drowsy (GCS 13). Severe dehydration (sunken eyes, dry mucous membranes, reduced skin turgor, CRT >3 seconds). Kussmaul breathing (deep, rapid, sighing). Fruity/acetone breath odor. Diffuse abdominal tenderness (DKA pseudo-abdomen). Tachycardic, hypotensive. No focal neurological deficit. BMI 16 (underweight).
investigations: Blood glucose: 480 mg/dL. ABG: pH 7.08, HCO3 6, PaCO2 18 (severe metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation). Serum ketones: >6 mmol/L (strongly positive). Anion gap: 28 (elevated - anion gap metabolic acidosis). Na+: 128 (pseudohyponatremia - corrected Na+ 135), K+: 5.5 (elevated initially but total body K+ depleted), Creatinine: 1.5 (prerenal AKI). Urine: Ketones 4+, Glucose 4+. HbA1c: 13.5% (indicating weeks-months of uncontrolled DM). C-peptide: 0.1 ng/mL (very low - confirms T1DM). Anti-GAD antibodies: Positive. CBC: WBC 18,000 (stress leucocytosis). Lipase: 280 (mild elevation - DKA can cause pancreatitis).
diagnosis: Severe diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) in newly diagnosed Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus
learning_points: DKA triad: Hyperglycemia (>250) + Ketosis + Metabolic acidosis (pH <7.3, HCO3 <18)
Severity: Mild (pH 7.25-7.3), Moderate (7.0-7.24), Severe (<7.0)
Fluid first: 0.9% NS 15-20 mL/kg/hr first hour, then adjust. Total deficit 5-10% body weight
Insulin: IV regular insulin 0.1 U/kg/hr infusion - do NOT bolus in children (cerebral edema risk)
Potassium: Replace if <5.3 mEq/L BEFORE starting insulin (total body K+ is depleted despite normal/high serum K+)
Cerebral edema: Most feared complication in children - headache, bradycardia, altered GCS during treatment
india_context: T1DM prevalence in India is increasing. Many patients present in DKA at diagnosis due to delayed recognition. Rural areas often lack blood gas and ketone testing. RSSDI (Research Society for Study of Diabetes in India) publishes DKA management protocols adapted for Indian settings. Insulin is available free under NPCDCS program.

title: Sepsis with Multi-Organ Dysfunction - Urosepsis
chief_complaint: High fever, confusion, and low blood pressure
presentation: A 68-year-old woman with poorly controlled diabetes presents with high fever, rigors, confusion, and hypotension for 24 hours. She has had urinary symptoms (dysuria, frequency) for 5 days which she ignored. She has a recent history of ureteric stent placement for urolithiasis.
history: Dysuria and frequency for 5 days, initially treated with norfloxacin by local doctor. Fever with rigors for 2 days, high-grade. Confusion since morning. Low urine output. Known T2DM for 15 years (HbA1c 10%). Ureteric stent placed 3 weeks ago for right ureteric calculus. Hypertension on amlodipine. Previous UTI 3 months ago (E. coli, fluoroquinolone-resistant). No allergies.
physical_exam: Confused (GCS 12), febrile, diaphoretic. Warm peripheries initially (warm shock). Tachycardic, hypotensive (MAP 52 mmHg). Suprapubic tenderness. Right renal angle tenderness. Costovertebral angle tenderness right. No meningism. Reduced urine output (100 mL in 12 hours). Mottled skin on knees.
investigations: qSOFA score: 3/3 (GCS <15, SBP <100, RR ≥22). SOFA score: 12. Blood cultures x 2: E. coli (ESBL-producing, fluoroquinolone-resistant, sensitive to meropenem). Urine culture: E. coli (same resistance pattern). CBC: WBC 22,000 (left shift, toxic granulations), Hb 10, Platelets 65,000 (DIC developing). CRP: 320. Procalcitonin: 45 ng/mL (severely elevated). Lactate: 6.5 mmol/L (>4 = septic shock). ABG: Metabolic acidosis, pH 7.22. Renal: Creatinine 3.5 (baseline 1.2), K+ 5.8. LFT: Bilirubin 3.5, AST 180 (shock liver). INR: 1.8, Fibrinogen low (DIC). RBS: 350. CT KUB: Right hydroureter with stent in situ, perinephric stranding (pyelonephritis), 8mm ureteric calculus.
diagnosis: Septic shock secondary to obstructive pyelonephritis/urosepsis (ESBL E. coli) with multi-organ dysfunction syndrome (AKI, DIC, metabolic acidosis)
learning_points: Sepsis-3 definition: Life-threatening organ dysfunction caused by dysregulated host response to infection (SOFA ≥2)
Septic shock: Sepsis + vasopressor requirement to maintain MAP ≥65 + lactate >2 despite fluids
Hour-1 bundle: Lactate, blood cultures, broad-spectrum antibiotics, 30 mL/kg crystalloid, vasopressors if needed
ESBL E. coli: Meropenem is first-line for severe infections. Avoid cephalosporins and fluoroquinolones
Source control is essential: Ureteric stent exchange/percutaneous nephrostomy for obstructed infected system
India-specific: High ESBL rates (>70% of E. coli) mandate empiric carbapenem use in severe sepsis from urinary source
india_context: India faces a dual burden: high sepsis incidence and extreme antimicrobial resistance. ESBL E. coli exceeds 70% in Indian hospitals. CRE (carbapenem-resistant Enterobacteriaceae) is emerging. ISCCM (Indian Society of Critical Care Medicine) adapts Surviving Sepsis Campaign guidelines for Indian settings. Procalcitonin-guided antibiotic stewardship is recommended.

title: Anaphylaxis to Wasp Sting
chief_complaint: Sudden breathlessness, rash, and dizziness after wasp sting
presentation: A 35-year-old coffee plantation worker from Coorg is brought to the rural health center 20 minutes after being stung by a wasp on his right arm. He developed rapid-onset generalized urticaria, facial and lip swelling, wheeze, and dizziness. He has a history of a similar but milder reaction to a bee sting 2 years ago.
history: Stung by wasp 20 minutes ago on right forearm. Within 5 minutes: Itching, generalized urticaria (hives). Within 10 minutes: Lip and tongue swelling, difficulty breathing, voice change (hoarse). Within 15 minutes: Dizziness, feeling faint, nausea. Previous mild reaction to bee sting 2 years ago (local swelling and mild hives only, resolved with antihistamines). No adrenaline auto-injector prescribed. No food allergies. No medications.
physical_exam: Anxious, tachycardic, hypotensive. Angioedema: Swollen lips, tongue, periorbital edema. Generalized urticaria (raised, erythematous, itchy wheals). Stridor (laryngeal edema). Bilateral wheeze (bronchospasm). Hypotensive with tachycardia. Right forearm: Sting site with local swelling.
investigations: Clinical diagnosis - no investigations needed before treatment. Serum tryptase: 48 ng/mL (elevated, confirms mast cell degranulation - send within 1-4 hours). IgE to wasp venom: To be done at follow-up (confirms specific allergy).
diagnosis: Anaphylaxis (Grade III, severe) to Hymenoptera (wasp) venom with anaphylactic shock
learning_points: Anaphylaxis is a CLINICAL diagnosis - do NOT delay treatment for investigations
IM Adrenaline (epinephrine) 0.5 mg (1:1000) mid-outer thigh is FIRST-LINE treatment - NOTHING else comes first
Position: Lay flat with legs elevated (unless respiratory distress - then sit up)
Repeat adrenaline every 5-15 minutes if no improvement (up to 3 doses)
Adjuncts: IV fluids (1-2L NS), nebulized salbutamol, IV hydrocortisone, IV chlorpheniramine
Biphasic reaction: Can recur 4-8 hours later - observe for minimum 6-12 hours
india_context: Anaphylaxis from Hymenoptera stings is common in plantation workers (coffee, rubber, tea) in South India. Adrenaline auto-injectors are not widely available or affordable in India. IM adrenaline from ampoules is the mainstay. Rural health centers may have limited resuscitation equipment. All patients with anaphylaxis should be referred for allergy testing and prescribed an adrenaline kit.

title: Snake Bite - Russell's Viper Envenomation
chief_complaint: Snake bite on foot with progressive swelling and bleeding
presentation: A 30-year-old farmer is brought to the district hospital 2 hours after being bitten by a snake on his right foot while walking through paddy fields at dusk. The snake was identified as a Russell's viper (Daboia russelii) based on a photo taken by a bystander. He has progressive swelling of the right leg, bleeding from the bite site, and blood-stained urine.
history: Bitten 2 hours ago while walking barefoot through paddy field at dusk. Felt sharp pain on right foot. Saw the snake briefly - brown with chain-like pattern (Russell's viper). Applied tourniquet at home (should be removed). Progressive swelling from foot to mid-thigh. Bleeding from bite site and gums. Blood in urine since 30 minutes. Nausea, vomiting. Abdominal pain. No traditional healer treatment. No prior snake bite.
physical_exam: Anxious, in pain. Right foot: Two fang marks, significant local swelling extending to mid-thigh, ecchymosis, tender. Whole blood clotting test (20-minute WBCT): Non-clotting (positive - confirms coagulopathy). Bleeding from gums and IV sites. Hematuria (dark red urine). No ptosis (no neurotoxicity). No respiratory distress. Blood pressure low.
investigations: 20-minute WBCT: Non-clotting (single most important bedside test in resource-limited settings). CBC: Hb 9.5 (blood loss + hemolysis), Platelets 45,000 (VICC - venom-induced consumption coagulopathy). Coagulation: PT >120 seconds, APTT >180 seconds, Fibrinogen <50 (DIC/VICC). D-dimer: >10,000. Peripheral smear: Schistocytes and spherocytes (microangiopathic hemolytic anemia). Renal: Creatinine 3.8 (AKI from direct nephrotoxicity + hemoglobinuria + myoglobinuria). LDH: 1200 (hemolysis). CPK: 5500 (rhabdomyolysis). Urine: Hemoglobinuria, myoglobinuria. CXR: Normal.
diagnosis: Russell's viper envenomation with venom-induced consumption coagulopathy (VICC), acute kidney injury, and rhabdomyolysis
learning_points: India's 'Big Four' venomous snakes: Russell's viper, Common cobra, Common krait, Saw-scaled viper
20-minute WBCT: Place 2-5 mL blood in clean glass tube, leave undisturbed for 20 min - if non-clotting, confirms coagulopathy
Anti-snake venom (ASV) polyvalent: 10 vials (100 mL) IV infusion over 1 hour - repeat if WBCT still non-clotting at 6 hours
Russell's viper triad: Coagulopathy + AKI + Local swelling (can also cause neurotoxicity in some regions)
Do NOT: Tourniquet, incision, suction, ice, traditional remedies - all harmful
AKI in Russell's viper: Cortical necrosis, ATN from hemoglobin/myoglobin - may need dialysis
india_context: India accounts for ~50% of global snakebite deaths (~58,000/year). Rural farmers walking barefoot at dusk are highest risk. Polyvalent ASV is manufactured by government (Haffkine Institute) and private companies. Available free at PHCs/CHCs. National Snakebite Protocol (NSEP) recommends ASV for any sign of systemic envenomation. Many patients first visit traditional healers, causing delay.

title: Acute Poisoning - Aluminum Phosphide (Celphos)
presentation: A 22-year-old woman from rural Punjab is brought to the ER 2 hours after ingesting one Celphos (aluminum phosphide) tablet with suicidal intent following a family dispute. She presents with vomiting, retrosternal burning, garlic odor on breath, and progressive hypotension. This is a medical emergency with very high mortality.
history: Ingested one Celphos (3g aluminum phosphide) tablet 2 hours ago. Suicidal intent after family dispute (dowry-related harassment by in-laws). Vomited immediately after ingestion (may have reduced absorption). Retrosternal and epigastric burning pain. Progressive dizziness and breathlessness. Family reports garlic-like odor on her breath and in vomitus. No other co-ingestants. Previously healthy. No psychiatric history.
physical_exam: Agitated, then becoming obtunded. Garlic/fish-like odor on breath. Profound hypotension (refractory to fluids). Tachycardic. Hypothermia (35.5°C). Cold peripheries. Abdomen: Epigastric tenderness. No hepatomegaly. Silver nitrate test on gastric aspirate: Positive (turns black - confirms phosphine gas).
investigations: Silver nitrate paper test: Positive (gastric aspirate/breath). ECG: Sinus tachycardia, ST-T changes diffuse, widened QRS, prolonged QTc. Serial ECGs show progressive conduction abnormalities. ABG: Severe metabolic acidosis pH 7.02, lactate 12 mmol/L. Blood glucose: 45 (hypoglycemia). Electrolytes: K+ 5.8, Mg2+ 1.0. Renal: Creatinine 2.5 (developing AKI). LFT: AST 500, ALT 400 (hepatic injury). Troponin: 2.5 (myocardial injury). CBC: Hb 14 (hemoconcentration). Methemoglobin: 8%. CXR: Pulmonary edema.
diagnosis: Acute aluminum phosphide (Celphos) poisoning with multi-organ failure (refractory shock, metabolic acidosis, hepatic and myocardial injury)
learning_points: AlP releases phosphine gas (PH3) in stomach - inhibits cytochrome C oxidase (cellular respiration) → same mechanism as cyanide
No specific antidote exists - mortality 40-80% despite best care
Key management: IV NaHCO3 (correct acidosis), IV MgSO4 (membrane stabilizer, antiarrhythmic), aggressive fluid resuscitation, vasopressors (noradrenaline)
Coconut oil/liquid paraffin via NG tube may reduce phosphine absorption (unproven but widely used in India)
Do NOT induce vomiting or gastric lavage with KMnO4 (old practice) - use NaHCO3 lavage
Refractory shock is the usual cause of death - may need VA-ECMO in select cases
india_context: AlP (sold as Celphos, Quickphos) is the most common cause of poisoning deaths in North India (Punjab, Haryana, Rajasthan, UP). Used as a grain preservative, freely available in agricultural shops. India's Supreme Court has recommended restricting sale. Punjab has the highest AlP poisoning rates. Dowry harassment and agricultural debt are common precipitants. MgSO4 protocol (Agra protocol) has improved survival.

title: Acute Myocardial Infarction with Cardiogenic Shock
presentation: A 55-year-old shopkeeper collapses in his shop with crushing chest pain, profuse sweating, and breathlessness. He is brought to the nearest hospital (non-PCI capable, 2 hours from PCI center). He has a history of diabetes and smoking. ECG shows extensive anterior STEMI.
history: Crushing retrosternal chest pain for 1.5 hours, radiating to left arm and jaw. Profuse sweating. Nausea, one episode of vomiting. Progressive breathlessness. Near-syncope. Known T2DM for 10 years (on metformin, glimepiride). Smokes 20 cigarettes/day for 30 years. Family history: Father MI at 50. Known hypertension (on telmisartan). Overweight.
physical_exam: Cold, clammy, diaphoretic. Altered sensorium (drowsy). Hypotensive, tachycardic. JVP elevated. S3 gallop. Bilateral basal crepitations up to mid-zones (Killip Class III). No murmur (rule out VSR, acute MR). Weak peripheral pulses.
investigations: ECG: ST elevation V1-V6, I, aVL (extensive anterior STEMI), ST depression II, III, aVF (reciprocal). Q waves developing. Troponin I: 25 ng/mL (markedly elevated). Bedside echo: Anterior and apical akinesis, LVEF 25%, no MR, no VSR, no pericardial effusion, no RV dilation. RBS: 350. Creatinine: 1.3. Lactate: 6 mmol/L.
diagnosis: Acute extensive anterior STEMI with cardiogenic shock (Killip Class III-IV)
learning_points: STEMI + cardiogenic shock: Primary PCI is the treatment of choice regardless of time delay
If PCI not available within 120 minutes: Thrombolyse (tenecteplase weight-based bolus) and transfer (pharmaco-invasive strategy)
Cardiogenic shock management: Vasopressors (norepinephrine first-line), inotropes (dobutamine), mechanical support (IABP/Impella)
Do NOT give beta-blockers or morphine in cardiogenic shock
Pharmaco-invasive strategy: Thrombolysis → Angiography within 3-24 hours at PCI center
STEMI diagnosis: ST elevation ≥2mm in V1-V3, ≥1mm in other leads, or new LBBB
india_context: India has limited PCI-capable hospitals (~600 catheterization labs for 1.4 billion people). The STEMI India and Kerala ACS registry showed only 20-30% of STEMI patients receive timely reperfusion. Pharmaco-invasive strategy (thrombolysis + transfer) is the pragmatic approach for most Indian patients. Tenecteplase is available at district hospitals under NHM. Hub-and-spoke networks are being developed.

title: Heat Stroke during Heat Wave
chief_complaint: Found unconscious in the street during extreme heat
presentation: A 50-year-old construction laborer is found unconscious on a road in Nagpur during a May heat wave (ambient temperature 47°C). He was working outdoors without shade or adequate water. Bystanders report he complained of headache and dizziness before collapsing. His skin is hot and dry (not sweating). Core temperature is 41.5°C.
history: Working on construction site since 8 AM under direct sun. No shade breaks. Drinking minimal water (financial constraints). Complained of severe headache, dizziness, and nausea at 2 PM. Collapsed at 2:30 PM. Found by bystanders who called ambulance. No prior heat illness. No medications. Takes no breaks due to daily wage pressure. Heat wave in Nagpur (47°C for past 5 days).
physical_exam: Unconscious (GCS 6). HOT, DRY skin (anhidrotic heat stroke - sweating has stopped). Core temperature 41.5°C (rectal). Tachycardic, hypotensive. Bilateral plantar extensors. Pupils equal, sluggishly reactive. No focal neurological deficit. No meningism. Skin: No rash. Dry mucous membranes.
investigations: Core temperature: 41.5°C. CBC: WBC 16,000, Hb 18 (hemoconcentration), Platelets 85,000 (DIC developing). Renal: Creatinine 3.2, K+ 5.8. CPK: 15,000 (severe rhabdomyolysis). LDH: 1200. LFT: AST 800, ALT 600 (heat-related hepatic injury). Coagulation: INR 2.5, Fibrinogen 80, D-dimer elevated (DIC). ABG: Metabolic acidosis, lactate 8. Urine: Dark brown (myoglobinuria). CT brain: No acute findings (rule out stroke/bleed).
diagnosis: Exertional heat stroke with multi-organ dysfunction (rhabdomyolysis, AKI, DIC, hepatic injury)
learning_points: Heat stroke: Core temperature >40°C + CNS dysfunction (confusion, seizures, coma)
Classic (non-exertional) vs Exertional heat stroke - both are emergencies
COOL FIRST, TRANSPORT SECOND - rapid cooling within 30 minutes saves lives
Best cooling methods: Cold water immersion (gold standard), evaporative cooling (spray water + fan), ice packs to groin/axillae/neck
Target: Reduce core temperature to 39°C within 30 minutes, then to 38.5°C
Complications: Rhabdomyolysis, DIC, AKI, hepatic failure, ARDS, cerebral edema
india_context: India experiences devastating heat waves - 2015 Andhra/Telangana heat wave killed >2500 people. Nagpur, Rajasthan, UP, and Telangana are worst affected. Daily wage workers (construction, agriculture) cannot afford to stop working. NDMA has issued heat action plans for vulnerable cities. ICMR recommends: ORS availability at worksites, mandatory shade breaks, early morning work schedules.

title: Drowning with Near-Drowning Complications
chief_complaint: Pulled out of backwater canal, not breathing
presentation: An 8-year-old boy is pulled from a backwater canal in Alappuzha, Kerala after an estimated 3-4 minute submersion. He was playing near the canal unsupervised. Bystanders initiated mouth-to-mouth breathing. On ambulance arrival, he has gasping respirations and is cyanotic.
history: Playing near backwater canal with friends. Fell in at approximately 4 PM. Estimated submersion time 3-4 minutes. Friends called for help. Neighbor pulled him out - not breathing, blue. Bystander initiated mouth-to-mouth breathing. Some water came out. Gasping respirations started. Ambulance arrived in 15 minutes. Freshwater drowning. No known medical conditions. Cannot swim. No seizure history.
physical_exam: Hypothermic (34.5°C). Cyanotic. Gasping/agonal respirations. Bradycardic (HR 50). GCS 4 (E1V1M2). Bilateral coarse crepitations (pulmonary edema from aspirated water). Frothy sputum from mouth. Distended abdomen (swallowed water). Pupils: Dilated bilaterally but reactive sluggishly.
investigations: ABG: pH 7.10, PaCO2 60, PaO2 35 (on NRM oxygen), HCO3 14 (mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis). SpO2: 60% on room air → 82% on 100% NRM. CXR: Bilateral diffuse alveolar infiltrates (pulmonary edema/ARDS). Electrolytes: Na+ 130, K+ 5.2. Blood glucose: 55. Renal: Normal. CBC: Hb 10, WBC 12,000. Lactate: 7. Core temperature: 34.5°C.
diagnosis: Freshwater drowning with non-fatal submersion injury, pulmonary edema, hypothermia, and hypoxic encephalopathy risk
differentials: Long QT syndrome triggered by cold water
learning_points: Drowning is the 3rd leading cause of unintentional injury death globally
Key pathology: Aspiration → surfactant washout → alveolar collapse → V/Q mismatch → hypoxemia → multi-organ injury
Freshwater: Hypotonic → rapid alveolar absorption → pulmonary edema. Saltwater: Hypertonic → fluid drawn into alveoli
Treatment: BLS first (rescue breaths are priority over compressions in drowning), then ARDS management protocol
All drowning patients with any symptoms need 24-hour observation (delayed pulmonary edema)
Hypothermia may be protective for brain ('nobody is dead until they are warm and dead')
india_context: India reports ~40,000 drowning deaths annually (2nd highest globally). Kerala backwaters, rivers during monsoon, and open wells are major hazards. Children are most vulnerable. ICMR recommends: Swimming training for children, fencing of water bodies, community CPR training. National guidelines for drowning prevention were released in 2021.
